7-1-1.graph_title: Percentage of population with access to electricity
7-1-1.indicator_name: Proportion of population with access to electricity
7-1-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 7: Ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all
7-1-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 7.1: By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services
7-1-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 7.1.1: Proportion of population with access to electricity
7-1-1.STAT_CONC_DEF__GLOBAL: Access to electricity is the percentage of population with access to electricity. Electrification data are collected from industry, national surveys and international sources.
7-1-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 7: Ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all
7-1-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 7.1: By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services
7-1-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 7.1.1: Proportion of population with access to electricity
7-1-1.STAT_CONC_DEF: Electrification data are collected from industry, national surveys and international sources.
7-1-1.SOURCE_TYPE: Access to electricity (% of population) - United Kingdom
7-1-1.REC_USE_LIM: Data represents the whole of the United Kingdom as opposed to Liverpool.

4-c-1.indicator_name: Proportion of teachers with the minimum required qualifications, by education level
4-c-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 4: Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4-c-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 4.c: By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States
4-c-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 4.c.1: Proportion of teachers with the minimum required qualifications, by education level
4-c-1.SDG_CUSTODIAN_AGENCIES__GLOBAL: United Nations Education and Scientific Cultural Organisation - Institute of Statistics (UNESCO-UIS)
4-c-1.REC_USE_LIM__GLOBAL:
Data is based on state-funded schools which includes - nursery, primary, secondary, special and centrally employed schools.

The proportion of qualified teachers includes both full and part time teachers. An unqualified teacher is either a trainee working towards qualified teacher status (QTS); an overseas trained teacher who has not exceeded the four years they are allowed to teach without having QTS; or an instructor who has a particular skill who can be employed for so long as a qualified teacher is not available.
4-c-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 4: Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4-c-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 4.c: By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States
4-c-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 4.c.1: Proportion of teachers with the minimum required qualifications, by education level
4-c-1.REC_USE_LIM:
Data is based on state funded public schools. All public schools include - nursery, primary, secondary, special and centrally employed schools. The proportion of qualified teachers includes both full and part time teachers. 

An unqualified teacher is either a trainee working towards qualified teacher status (QTS); an overseas trained teacher who has not exceeded the four years they are allowed to teach without having QTS; or an instructor who has a particular skill who can be employed for so long as a qualified teacher is not available.

2-2-2.graph_title: Percentage of 4 to 5 year old children classified as underweight or overweight (including obese)
2-2-2.indicator_available: Prevalence of underweight or overweight (including obese) 4 to 5 year old children based on Body Mass Index (BMI) classifications
2-2-2.indicator_name: Prevalence of malnutrition (weight for height >+2 or <-2 standard deviation from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards) among children under 5 years of age, by type (wasting and overweight)
2-2-2.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 2: End hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture
2-2-2.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 2.2: By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons
2-2-2.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: 2.2.2: Prevalence of malnutrition (weight for height >+2 or <-2 standard deviation from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards) among children under 5 years of age, by type (wasting and overweight)
2-2-2.CONTACT_ORGANISATION__GLOBAL: United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), World Health Organisation (WHO), World Bank (WB)
2-2-2.IND_DEF_CON_CLASS__GLOBAL: The prevalence of undernourishment is an estimate of the proportion of the population whose habitual food consumption is insufficient to provide the dietary energy levels that are required to maintain a normal active and healthy life.
2-2-2.SDG_GOAL: Goal 2: End hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture
2-2-2.SDG_TARGET: Target 2.2: By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons
2-2-2.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 2.2.2: Prevalence of malnutrition (weight for height >+2 or <-2 standard deviation from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards) among children under 5 years of age, by type (wasting and overweight)
2-2-2.STAT_CONC_DEF: Children with low weight for age are known as underweight. Overweight and obesity is when a person is too heavy for his or her height. Body mass index (BMI) is an index of weight-for-height. It is defined as a person’s weight in kilograms divided by the square of his/her height in meters (kg/m²). The BMI classification of each child is derived by calculating the child’s BMI centile. This calculation uses age and sex as well as height and weight to take into account different growth patterns in children at different ages.

3-c-1.graph_title: Percentage of population working in Human Health And Social Work Activities
3-c-1.indicator_available: Percentage of population working in Human Health And Social Work Activities
3-c-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-c-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 3c: Substantially increase health financing and the recruitment, development, training and retention of the health workforce in developing countries, especially in least developed countries and small island developing States
3-c-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 3.c.1: Health worker density and distribution
3-c-1.STAT_CONC_DEF__GLOBAL: Density of medical doctors - The density of medical doctors is defined as the number of medical doctors , including generalists and specialist medical practitioners per 10,000 population in the given national and/or subnational area. Density of nursing and midwifery personnel - The density of nursing and midwifery personnel is defined as the number of nursing and midwifery personnel per 10,000 population in the given national and/or subnational area. Density of dentists - The density of dentists is defined as the number of dentists per 10,000 population in the given national and/or subnational area. Density of pharmacists - The density of pharmacists is defined as the number of pharmacists per 10,000 population in the given national and/or subnational area.
3-c-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-c-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 3c: Substantially increase health financing and the recruitment, development, training and retention of the health workforce in developing countries, especially in least developed countries and small island developing States
3-c-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 3.c.1: Health worker density and distribution
3-c-1.SOURCE_TYPE: Nomis - Human Health And Social Work Activities Liverpool

3-4-2.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-4-2.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 3.4: By 2030, reduce by one third premature mortality from non-communicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being
3-4-2.SDG_GOAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-4-2.SDG_TARGET: Target 3.4: By 2030, reduce by one third premature mortality from non-communicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being
3-4-2.SOURCE_TYPE: Suicides in England and Wales by local authority
3-4-2.REC_USE_LIM: The data is based on a 3 year average. The year given is the middle year of the sample, for example the sample years between 2001-03 is displayed as 2002. Data from Table 2.

5-1-1.indicator_name: Whether or not legal frameworks are in place to promote, enforce and monitor equality and non‐discrimination on the basis of sex
5-1-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 5: Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls
5-1-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 5.1: End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere
5-1-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 5.1.1: Whether or not legal frameworks are in place to promote, enforce and monitor equality and non‐discrimination on the basis of sex
5-1-1.SDG_CUSTODIAN_AGENCIES__GLOBAL: UN Women, World Bank (WB), Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)
5-1-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 5: Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls
5-1-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 5.1: End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere
5-1-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 5.1.1: Whether or not legal frameworks are in place to promote, enforce and monitor equality and non‐discrimination on the basis of sex
5-1-1.STAT_CONC_DEF: Gender pay gap is based on the percentage difference between median wages. The workplace population in a local authority is defined as the population whose usual place of work is in that local authority, including individuals who live and work in the local authority and individuals who work in the local authority but commute from a home elsewhere within England or Wales. The resident analysis refers to those who reside in the local authority, however the workplace does not have to be within the same local authority.

3-5-1.graph_title: Percentage of drug and alcohol users who have completed treatment
3-5-1.indicator_available: Percentage of drug and alcohol users who have completed treatment
3-5-1.indicator_name: Coverage of treatment interventions (pharmacological, psychosocial and rehabilitation and aftercare services) for substance use disorders
3-5-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-5-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 3.5: Strengthen the prevention and treatment of substance abuse, including narcotic drug abuse and harmful use of alcohol
3-5-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 3.5.1: Coverage of treatment interventions (pharmacological, psychosocial and rehabilitation and aftercare services) for substance use disorders
3-5-1.SDG_CUSTODIAN_AGENCIES__GLOBAL: World Health Organisation (WHO), United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC)
3-5-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-5-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 3.5: Strengthen the prevention and treatment of substance abuse, including narcotic drug abuse and harmful use of alcohol
3-5-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 3.5.1: Coverage of treatment interventions (pharmacological, psychosocial and rehabilitation and aftercare services) for substance use disorders
3-5-1.SOURCE_TYPE: Successful completion of drug treatment - opiate users, Successful completion of drug treatment - non-opiate users, Successful completion of alcohol treatment
3-5-1.REC_USE_LIM: The data shows the percentage of users who complete treatment successfully and do not re-present to treatment in 6 months. Achieving this outcome demonstrates improvements in well-being and health, resulting in increased longevity and fewer hospital admissions related to drug and alcohol use.

7-2-1.indicator_name: Renewable energy share in the total final energy consumption
7-2-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 7: Ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all
7-2-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 7.2: By 2030, increase substantially the share of renewable energy in the global energy mix
7-2-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 7.2.1: Renewable energy share in the total final energy consumption
7-2-1.SDG_CUSTODIAN_AGENCIES__GLOBAL: International Energy Agency (IEA), United Nations Statistics Division (UNSD), United Nations’ inter-agency mechanism on energy (UN Energy), SE4ALL Global Tracking Framework Consortium
7-2-1.STAT_CONC_DEF__GLOBAL: The renewable energy share in total final consumption is the percentage of final consumption of energy that is derived from renewable resources. Renewable energy consumption includes consumption of energy derived from hydroelectric power, wind, wave, tidal, solar photovoltaic, geothermal aquifers, landfill gas, sewage gas, biogas from autogen, municipal solid waste, poultry litter, straw, wood, charcoal, liquid bio-fuels, bioethanol, biodiesel and biomass.
7-2-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 7: Ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all
7-2-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 7.2: By 2030, increase substantially the share of renewable energy in the global energy mix
7-2-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 7.2.1: Renewable energy share in the total final energy consumption
7-2-1.CONTACT_ORGANISATION: Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy
7-2-1.STAT_CONC_DEF: A megawatt hour (Mwh) is equal to 1,000 Kilowatt hours (Kwh). It is equal to 1,000 kilowatts of electricity used continuously for one hour. It is about equivalent to the amount of electricity used by about 330 homes during one hour.
7-2-1.SOURCE_TYPE: Renewable electricity by local authority, 2014 to 2019
7-2-1.DATA_SOURCE: Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy

3-3-1.indicator_available: New HIV diagnosis rate / 100,000 population aged 15 and over
3-3-1.indicator_name: Number of new HIV infections per 1,000 uninfected population, by sex, age and key populations
3-3-1.SOURCE_TYPE__GLOBAL: PHE Fingertips: Liverpool Public Health Profile
3-3-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases
3-3-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 3.3.1:Number of new HIV infections per 1,000 uninfected population, by sex, age and key populations

3-a-1.indicator_available: Percentage of population aged 18 and over who smoke cigarettes
3-a-1.indicator_name: Age-standardized prevalence of current tobacco use among persons aged 15 years and older

3-a-1.SDG_CUSTODIAN_AGENCIES__GLOBAL: World Health Organization (WHO), Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC)
3-a-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-a-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 3.a: Strengthen the implementation of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control in all countries, as appropriate

4-2-2.computation_units: Percentage (%) of children benefitting from early funded education places
4-2-2.graph_title: Percentage (%) of children benefitting from early funded education places
4-2-2.indicator_available: Percentage (%) of children benefitting from early funded education places
4-2-2.indicator_name: Participation rate in organized learning (one year before the official primary entry age), by sex
4-2-2.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 4: Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4-2-2.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 4.2: By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre‐primary education so that they are ready for primary education
4-2-2.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 4.2.2: Participation rate in organized learning (one year before the official primary entry age), by sex
4-2-2.SDG_CUSTODIAN_AGENCIES__GLOBAL: United Nations Education and Scientific Cultural Organisation - Institute of Statistics (UNESCO-UIS)
4-2-2.REC_USE_LIM__GLOBAL: This indicator is being used as an approximation of the UN SDG Indicator. Where possible, we will work to identify or develop UK data to meet the global indicator specification. This indicator has been identified in collaboration with topic experts.
4-2-2.SDG_GOAL: Goal 4: Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4-2-2.SDG_TARGET: Target 4.2: By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre‐primary education so that they are ready for primary education
4-2-2.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 4.2.2: Participation rate in organized learning (one year before the official primary entry age), by sex
4-2-2.UNIT_MEASURE: Percentage (%) of children benefitting from early funded education places
4-2-2.SOURCE_TYPE: Department for Education - Provision for children under 5, 2019 - main tables

3-5-2.graph_title: Admission episodes (alcohol-related conditions and alcohol-specific conditions) and alcohol related mortality
3-5-2.indicator_available: Admission episodes (alcohol-related conditions and alcohol-specific conditions) and alcohol related mortality
3-5-2.indicator_name: Alcohol per capita consumption (aged 15 years and older) within a calendar year in litres of pure alcohol

3-5-2.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 3.6.1: Death rate due to road traffic injuries
3-5-2.SDG_GOAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-5-2.SDG_TARGET: Target 3.6: By 2020, halve the number of global deaths and injuries from road traffic accidents

4-6-1.graph_title: Proportions of entries at GCSE level English and Mathematics achieving a pass grade
4-6-1.indicator_available: Proportion of entries at GCSE level English and Mathematics achieving a pass grade
4-6-1.indicator_name: Proportion of population in a given age group achieving at least a fixed level of proficiency in functional (a) literacy and (b) numeracy skills, by sex
4-6-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 4: Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4-6-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 4.6: By 2030, ensure that all youth and a substantial proportion of adults, both men and women, achieve literacy and numeracy
4-6-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 4.6.1: Proportion of population in a given age group achieving at least a fixed level of proficiency in functional (a) literacy and (b) numeracy skills, by sex
4-6-1.SDG_CUSTODIAN_AGENCIES__GLOBAL: United Nations Education and Scientific Cultural Organisation - Institute of Statistics (UNESCO-UIS)
4-6-1.STAT_CONC_DEF__GLOBAL: The fixed level of proficiency is the benchmark of basic knowledge in a domain (literacy or numeracy) measured through learning assessments. Currently, there are no common standards validated by the international community or countries. The indicator shows data published by each of the agencies and organizations specialised in cross-national learning assessments.
4-6-1.REC_USE_LIM__GLOBAL: This indicator is being used as an approximation of the UN SDG Indicator. Where possible, we will work to identify or develop UK data to meet the global indicator specification. This indicator has been identified in collaboration with topic experts.
4-6-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 4: Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4-6-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 4.6: By 2030, ensure that all youth and a substantial proportion of adults, both men and women, achieve literacy and numeracy
4-6-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 4.6.1: Proportion of population in a given age group achieving at least a fixed level of proficiency in functional (a) literacy and (b) numeracy skills, by sex

3-9-1.graph_title: Fraction of annual all-cause adult mortality attributable to anthropogenic (human-made) particulate air pollution (measured as fine particulate matter, PM2.5)
3-9-1.indicator_available: Fraction of all-cause adult mortality attributable to ambient anthropogenic particulate air pollution
3-9-1.indicator_name: Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution
3-9-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-9-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 3.9: By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination
3-9-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 3.9.1: Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution
3-9-1.STAT_CONC_DEF__GLOBAL: Fraction of annual all-cause adult mortality attributable to anthropogenic (human-made) particulate air pollution (measured as fine particulate matter, PM2.5). Mortality burden associated with long-term exposure to anthropogenic particulate air pollution at current levels, expressed as the percentage of annual deaths from all causes in those aged 30+. PM2.5 means the mass (in micrograms) per cubic metre of air of individual particles with an aerodynamic diameter generally less than 2.5 micrometers. PM2.5 is also known as fine particulate matter.
3-9-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-9-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 3.9: By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination
3-9-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 3.9.1: Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution
3-9-1.STAT_CONC_DEF: Expressed as a percentage of annual deaths from all causes in those aged 30+.  PM2.5 means the mass (in micrograms) per cubic metre of air of individual particles with an aerodynamic diameter generally less than 2.5 micrometers. PM2.5 is also known as fine particulate matter.
3-9-1.SOURCE_TYPE: Fraction of mortality attributable to particulate air pollution

1-5-1.graph_title: Deaths due to 'Exposure to forces of nature'
1-5-1.indicator_available: Deaths due to 'Exposure to forces of nature'
1-5-1.indicator_name: Number of deaths, missing persons and directly affected persons attributed to disasters per 100,000 population
1-5-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 1: End poverty in all its forms everywhere
1-5-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 1.5: By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters
1-5-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Target 1.5.1: Number of deaths, missing persons and directly affected persons attributed to disasters per 100,000 population
1-5-1.SDG_CUSTODIAN_AGENCIES__GLOBAL: United Nations International Strategy for Disaster Reduction (UNISDR)
1-5-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 1: End poverty in all its forms everywhere
1-5-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 1.5: By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters
1-5-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 1.1.1: Proportion of the population living below the international poverty line by sex, age, employment status and geographic location (urban/rural)
1-5-1.SDG_SERIES_DESCR: Target 1.5.1: Number of deaths, missing persons and directly affected persons attributed to disasters per 100,000 population
1-5-1.REC_USE_LIM: Data used - X30-X39 Exposure to forces of nature

3-3-2.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-3-2.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 3.3: By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases
3-3-2.STAT_CONC_DEF__GLOBAL: The tuberculosis incidence per 100,000 population as defined as the estimated number of new and relapse TB cases (all forms of TB, including cases in people living with HIV) arising in a given year, expressed as a rate per 100 000 population.
3-3-2.SDG_GOAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-3-2.SDG_TARGET: Target 3.3: By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases
3-3-2.SOURCE_TYPE: PHE Liverpool Public Health Profile - TB incidence
3-3-2.REC_USE_LIM: The data is based on a 3 year average due to sample size. The year given is the middle year of the sample. For example the sample years between 2001-2003 is displayed as 2002.

3-9-2.graph_title: Mortality rate due to WASH attributable factors
3-9-2.indicator_available: Mortality rate due to WASH attributable factors
3-9-2.indicator_name: Mortality rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation and lack of hygiene (exposure to unsafe Water, Sanitation and Hygiene for All (WASH) services)
3-9-2.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-9-2.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 3.9: By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination
3-9-2.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 3.9.2: Mortality rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation and lack of hygiene (exposure to unsafe Water, Sanitation and Hygiene for All (WASH) services)
3-9-2.SDG_GOAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-9-2.SDG_TARGET: Target 3.9: By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination
3-9-2.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 3.9.2: Mortality rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation and lack of hygiene (exposure to unsafe Water, Sanitation and Hygiene for All (WASH) services)
3-9-2.STAT_CONC_DEF: Total figures are for Intestinal infectious diseases and do not include hookworm disease, Ascariasis and Trichriasis
3-9-2.SOURCE_TYPE: Mortality statistics - underlying cause, sex and age
3-9-2.REC_USE_LIM: Some figures are missing. Please note no breakdown data is available for cholera, typhoid and paratyphoyd fever, shigelossis, amoebiasis, other protozoal intestinal diseases, viral and other intestinal infections. No data is available for hookworm disease, Ascariasis and Trichuriasis and are not included in totals.

3-2-2.indicator_available: Number of neonatal deaths per 1,000 live births
3-2-2.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-2-2.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 3.2: By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under‐5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births
3-2-2.STAT_CONC_DEF__GLOBAL: Neonatal death is the death of a child of when the age of the child is under 28 days.
3-2-2.SDG_GOAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-2-2.SDG_TARGET: Target 3.2: By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under‐5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births
3-2-2.STAT_CONC_DEF: Neonatal death is defined as the death of an infant aged under 28 days.
3-2-2.SOURCE_TYPE: PHE Public Health Profiles - Neonatal mortality rate
3-2-2.REC_USE_LIM: The data is based on a 3 year average due to sample size. The year given is the middle year of the sample. For example the sample years between 2011-2013 is displayed as 2012.

3-b-1.indicator_name: Proportion of the target population covered by all vaccines included in their national programme
3-b-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-b-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 3.b: Support the research and development of vaccines and medicines for the communicable and non‐communicable diseases that primarily affect developing countries, provide access to affordable essential medicines and vaccines, in accordance with the Doha Declaration on the TRIPS Agreement and Public Health, which affirms the right of developing countries to use to the full the provisions in the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights regarding flexibilities to protect public health, and, in particular, provide access to medicines for all
3-b-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 3.b.1: Proportion of the target population covered by all vaccines included in their national programme
3-b-1.SDG_CUSTODIAN_AGENCIES__GLOBAL: World Health Organization (WHO), United Nations International Children’s Emergency Fund (UNICEF)

6-1-1.graph_title: Percentage (%) of population using safely managed drinking water services
6-1-1.indicator_name: Proportion of population using safely managed drinking water services
6-1-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 6: Ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all
6-1-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 6.1: By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all
6-1-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 6.1.1: Proportion of population using safely managed drinking water services
6-1-1.SDG_CUSTODIAN_AGENCIES__GLOBAL: World Health Organisation (WHO), United Nations Children’s Emergency Fund (UNICEF)
6-1-1.STAT_CONC_DEF__GLOBAL: WHO/UNICEF defines a safely managed drinking water as an improved water source that is accessible on premises, available when needed and free from faecal and priority chemical contamination. Improved water sources include - piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.
6-1-1.REC_USE_LIM__GLOBAL: In order to meet the criteria for a safely managed drinking water service, an improved water source should meet three criteria - it should be accessible on the premises (accessibility), water should be available when needed (availability), and the water supplied should be free from contamination (quality). Many countries lack data on one or more elements of safely managed drinking water. The WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP) provide national estimates only when data are available on drinking water quality and at least one of the other criteria (accessibility and availability). Regional and income group estimates are made when data are available for at least 30 percent of the population. Data on drinking water, sanitation and hygiene are produced by the Joint Monitoring Programme of the World Health Organization (WHO) and United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) based on administrative sources, national censuses and nationally representative household surveys. Data follows the UN specification for this indicator. This indicator has not been identified in collaboration with topic experts.
6-1-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 6: Ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all
6-1-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 6.1: By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all
6-1-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 6.1.1: Proportion of population using safely managed drinking water services
6-1-1.CONTACT_ORGANISATION: World Health Organisation (WHO), United Nations Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF)
6-1-1.STAT_CONC_DEF: WHO/UNICEF defines a safely managed drinking water as an improved water source that is accessible on premises, available when needed and free from faecal and priority chemical contamination. Improved water sources include - piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.
6-1-1.SOURCE_TYPE: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene
6-1-1.DATA_SOURCE: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene
6-1-1.REC_USE_LIM: This data represents the United Kingdom as opposed to Liverpool.

3-7-1.graph_title: The proportion of women using Sexual and Reproductive Health Services for contraception, by main method of contraception
3-7-1.indicator_available: The proportion of women using Sexual and Reproductive Health Services for contraception, by main method of contraception
3-7-1.indicator_name: Proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15–49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods
3-7-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-7-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 3.7: By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes
3-7-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 3.7.1: Proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15–49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods
3-7-1.STAT_CONC_DEF__GLOBAL: Sexual Reproductive Health (SRH) services include family planning services, community contraception clinics, integrated GUM and SRH services and young people’s services e.g. Brook advisory centres. IUD refers to intrauterine device. IU System refers to intrauterine system.
3-7-1.REC_USE_LIM__GLOBAL:
Data is not representative of the uptake of contraception methods across the whole population. Contraceptives can be obtained from other sources such as GPs or direct from pharmacies, whilst non-prescription items like condoms can be obtained easily without a visit to a medical specialist.

For analysis of contraception methods it is encouraged that data be presented as proportions rather than numbers. This is because the level of SRH service provision is constantly changing.
3-7-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-7-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 3.7: By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes
3-7-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 3.7.1: Proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15–49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods
3-7-1.STAT_CONC_DEF: Sexual Reproductive Health (SRH) services include family planning services, community contraception clinics, integrated GUM and SRH services and young people’s services such as Brook advisory centres. IUD refers to intrauterine device. IU System refers to intrauterine system.
3-7-1.REC_USE_LIM: Data is not representative of the uptake of contraception methods across the whole population. Contraceptives can be obtained from other sources such as GPs or direct from pharmacies, whilst non-prescription items like condoms can be obtained easily without a visit to a medical specialist. Excludes women where no main method of contraception was recorded during the year.

1-1-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 1: End poverty in all its forms everywhere
1-1-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 1.1: By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day
1-1-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 1.1.1: Proportion of the population living below the international poverty line by sex, age, employment status and geographic location (urban/rural)
1-1-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
## Definition:
The proportion of the employed population below the international poverty line of US$1.90 per day, also referred to as the working poverty rate, is defined as the share of employed persons living in households with per-capita consumption or income that is below the international poverty line of US$1.90.
## Concepts:
**Employment:** All persons of working age who, during a short reference period (one week), were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit.

**Poverty Line:** Threshold below which individuals in the reference population are considered poor and above which they are considered non-poor. The threshold is generally defined as the per-capita monetary requirements an individual needs to afford the purchase of a basic bundle of goods and services. For the purpose of this indicator, an absolute international poverty line of US$1.90 per day is used.

**Household in poverty:** Households are defined as poor if their income or consumption expenditure is below the poverty line taking into account the number of household members and composition (e.g., number of adults and children).

**Working poor:** Employed persons living in households that are classified as poor, that is, that have income or consumption levels below the poverty line used for measurement.

es.SDG_GOAL: Meta 1: Poner fin a la pobreza en todas sus formas y en todo el mundo
es.SDG_TARGET: Objetivo 1.1: De aquí a 2030, erradicar para todas las personas y en todo el mundo la pobreza extrema (actualmente se considera que sufren pobreza extrema las personas que viven con menos de 1,25 dólares de los Estados Unidos al día)
es.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicador 1.1.1: Proporción de la población que vive por debajo del umbral de pobreza internacional por sexo, edad, situación laboral y ubicación geográfica (urbana/rural)
es.STAT_CONC_DEF:
## Definición:
El indicador "proporción de la población por debajo del umbral de pobreza internacional" se define como el porcentaje de la población que vive con menos de 1,90 dólares al día a precios internacionales de 2011. La línea de pobreza internacional se fija actualmente en 1,90 dólares al día a precios internacionales de 2011.

## Conceptos:
Al evaluar la pobreza en un país determinado y la mejor manera de reducirla, naturalmente uno se enfoca en una línea de pobreza que se considera apropiada para ese país. Pero, ¿cómo hablamos de manera significativa sobre "la pobreza global"? Las líneas de pobreza entre países varían en términos de su poder adquisitivo y tienen un fuerte gradiente económico, de modo que los países más ricos tienden a adoptar niveles de vida más altos al definir la pobreza. Pero para medir consistentemente la pobreza absoluta global en términos de consumo, necesitamos tratar a dos personas con el mismo poder adquisitivo sobre los productos básicos de la misma manera - ambos son pobres o no lo son - incluso si viven en países diferentes.

Desde el Informe sobre el desarrollo mundial de 1990, el Banco Mundial se ha propuesto aplicar un estándar común para medir la pobreza extrema, anclado en lo que significa la pobreza en los países más pobres del mundo. El bienestar de las personas que viven en diferentes países se puede medir en una escala común ajustando las diferencias en el poder adquisitivo de las monedas. Para el Informe sobre el desarrollo mundial de 1990, se eligió el estándar de 1 dólar al día, medido a precios internacionales de 1985 y ajustado a la moneda local mediante PPA, porque era típico de las líneas de pobreza de los países de bajos ingresos en ese momento. A medida que evolucionan las diferencias en el costo de vida en todo el mundo, la línea de pobreza internacional debe actualizarse periódicamente utilizando nuevos datos de precios de PPA para reflejar estos cambios. El último cambio fue en octubre de 2015, cuando el Banco Mundial adoptó $ 1,90 como línea de pobreza internacional utilizando la PPA de 2011. Antes de eso, la actualización de 2008 estableció la línea de pobreza internacional en $ 1,25 utilizando la PPA de 2005. Las medidas de pobreza basadas en líneas de pobreza internacionales intentan mantener constante el valor real de la línea de pobreza en todos los países, como se hace al hacer comparaciones en el tiempo. Las primeras ediciones de los Indicadores de desarrollo mundial (WDI) del Banco Mundial' utilizaban las PPA de las Penn World Tables para convertir los valores en moneda local al poder adquisitivo equivalente medido en dólares estadounidenses. En ediciones posteriores se utilizaron estimaciones de la PPA de consumo de 1993, 2005 y 2011 elaboradas por el Programa de Comparación Internacional (PCI) del Banco Mundial'.

3-2-1.STAT_CONC_DEF__GLOBAL: Under-five mortality is the probability of a child born in a specific year or period dying before reaching the age of 5 years, if subject to age specific mortality rates of that period, expressed per 1000 live births.
3-2-1.REC_USE_LIM__GLOBAL: The data is based on a 3 year average. The year given is the middle year of the sample, for example the sample years between 2001-03 is displayed as 2002.

4-1-1.graph_title: Percentage of children achieving at least the expected proficiency level in Reading and Mathematics
4-1-1.indicator_available: Percentage of children achieving at least the expected proficiency level in Reading and Mathematics at ages 7 and 11
4-1-1.indicator_name: Proportion of children and young people (a) in grades 2/3; (b) at the end of primary; and (c) at the end of lower secondary achieving at least a minimum proficiency level in (i) reading and (ii) mathematics, by sex
4-1-1.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 4: Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4-1-1.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 4.1: By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes
4-1-1.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 4.1.1: Proportion of children and young people (a) in grades 2/3; (b) at the end of primary; and (c) at the end of lower secondary achieving at least a minimum proficiency level in (i) reading and (ii) mathematics, by sex
4-1-1.STAT_CONC_DEF__GLOBAL: At age 7, schools are categorised into infant schools (those with highest statutory pupil age of 7), primary schools (those with highest statutory pupil age between 8 and 11) and other schools (those with highest statutory pupil age greater than 11). At age 11, schools are categorised into primary schools (those with lowest statutory age below 7 and highest statutory age of 11), junior schools (those with lowest statutory age of 7 or above and highest statutory age of 11) and other schools (those with highest statutory age greater than 11 - this category includes middle and all-through schools. For age 16, minimum proficiency is defined for the purpose of this indicator as achieving a grade 4 or above.
4-1-1.SDG_GOAL: Goal 4: Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4-1-1.SDG_TARGET: Target 4.1: By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes
4-1-1.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 4.1.1: Proportion of children and young people (a) in grades 2/3; (b) at the end of primary; and (c) at the end of lower secondary achieving at least a minimum proficiency level in (i) reading and (ii) mathematics, by sex
4-1-1.STAT_CONC_DEF: Data are based on the National Curriculum for England. Children in key stage 1 are between the ages of 5 and 7. This covers years 1 and 2 in primary school. Children in key stage 2 and between the ages of 7 and 11. This covers years 3 to 6 in primary school.
4-1-1.SOURCE_TYPE: Key stage 1 statistics, Key stage 2 statistics

5-3-2.graph_title: Number of individuals the NHS has interacted with where FGM was identified
5-3-2.indicator_available: Number of individuals the NHS has interacted with where FGM was identified
5-3-2.indicator_name: Proportion of girls and women aged 15–49 years who have undergone female genital mutilation/cutting, by age
5-3-2.SDG_GOAL__GLOBAL: Goal 5: Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls
5-3-2.SDG_TARGET__GLOBAL: Target 5.3: Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation
5-3-2.SDG_INDICATOR__GLOBAL: Indicator 5.3.2: Proportion of girls and women aged 15–49 years who have undergone female genital mutilation/cutting, by age
5-3-2.STAT_CONC_DEF__GLOBAL: Female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C) refers to “all procedures involving partial or total removal of the female external genitalia or other injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons” (World Health Organization, Eliminating Female Genital Mutilation - An interagency statement, WHO, UNFPA, UNICEF, UNIFEM, OHCHR, UNHCR, UNECA, UNESCO, UNDP, UNAIDS, WHO, Geneva, 2008, p.4). The World Health Organisation defines the four types of female genital mutilation as follows - Type 1 - Partial or total removal of the clitoral glans (the external and visible part of the clitoris, which is a sensitive part of the female genitals, with the function of providing sexual pleasure to the woman), and/or the prepuce/clitoral hood (the fold of skin surrounding the clitoral glans). Type 2 - Partial or total removal of the clitoral glans and the labia minora (the inner folds of the vulva), with or without removal of the labia majora (the outer folds of skin of the vulva). Type 3 - (Often referred to as infibulation). Narrowing of the vaginal opening with the creation of a covering seal. The seal is formed by cutting and repositioning the labia minora, or labia majora. The covering of the vaginal opening is done with or without removal of the clitoral prepuce/clitoral hood and glans (Type I FGM). Type 4 - All other harmful procedures to the female genitalia for non-medical purposes, for example pricking, piercing, incising, scraping and cauterization.
5-3-2.SDG_GOAL: Goal 5: Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls
5-3-2.SDG_TARGET: Target 5.3: Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation
5-3-2.SDG_INDICATOR: Indicator 5.3.2: Proportion of girls and women aged 15–49 years who have undergone female genital mutilation/cutting, by age
5-3-2.STAT_CONC_DEF: Female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C) refers to “all procedures involving partial or total removal of the female external genitalia or other injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons” (World Health Organization, Eliminating Female Genital Mutilation - An interagency statement, WHO, UNFPA, UNICEF, UNIFEM, OHCHR, UNHCR, UNECA, UNESCO, UNDP, UNAIDS, WHO, Geneva, 2008, p.4). The World Health Organisation defines the four types of female genital mutilation as follows - Type 1 - Partial or total removal of the clitoral glans (the external and visible part of the clitoris, which is a sensitive part of the female genitals, with the function of providing sexual pleasure to the woman), and/or the prepuce/clitoral hood (the fold of skin surrounding the clitoral glans). Type 2 - Partial or total removal of the clitoral glans and the labia minora (the inner folds of the vulva), with or without removal of the labia majora (the outer folds of skin of the vulva). Type 3 - (Often referred to as infibulation). Narrowing of the vaginal opening with the creation of a covering seal. The seal is formed by cutting and repositioning the labia minora, or labia majora. The covering of the vaginal opening is done with or without removal of the clitoral prepuce/clitoral hood and glans (Type I FGM). Type 4 - All other harmful procedures to the female genitalia for non-medical purposes, for example pricking, piercing, incising, scraping and cauterization.
5-3-2.REC_USE_LIM: Values between 1-7 are rounded to 5. All other values are rounded to the nearest 5. 2. Individuals refers to all patients in the reporting period where FGM was identified or a procedure for FGM was undertaken. Each patient is only counted once.
